reviewText:

+ Character designs are creative and interesting; just the right mixture of weird and entertaining

reviewText:
Truly a masterpiece. Fight your way to the truth of an unhinged world through mobsters, monsters, deranged beings and dark creatures.
Zenozoik is a wonderful, vivid world, but this is no paradise. Forget the tales about the 'good savage', for this land is full of secrets and violence. Find out the reason of the brutal hunting you suffer from your own brothers, the secret crimes Ghat has come to know. In this first journey in Zenozoik, there'll be some revelations, but also questions that'll make you wish everything hidden to be brought into the open.
The world ACE Team has created is really unique, and you'll always feel that there's much more to see... and to fight. Because Zeno Clash is above all, a brawling game, and it excels on it. The extraordinary plot backs an addictive and satisfying combat system, and luckyly the game includes modes beyond the main history which will sate your thirst for beating throwing you right into the action, in the increasingly harder stages of a tower which progressive destruction will delight you by its smart use of physics.
Zeno Clash is an indispensable, which will remind you why some games deserve to be considered art; exalted visuals, surprising lore and relentless fights await you. Welcome to Zenozoik, brother.

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Zeno Clash is a first-person melee fighting game developed by ACE Team using Valve's famous Source Engine and released on Steam back in 2009.

The story begins with Ghat, the game's protagonist, waking up after being knocked out by an explosion which killed a creature known as Father-Mother who is the leader of a very powerful mafia like family in the small town of Halstedom. The protagonist Ghat is presumably one of Father-Mother's children who turned rogue and ran away from home and is now being pursued by his 'brothers and sisters' (enforcers of Father-Mother). Join him and his companion Deadra in a quest to discover the truth of about Ghat's past and trace back the series of events that led to the explosion.

PROS:+ Excellent use of the Source Engine
+ Good fisticuffs (melee) combat mechanic
+ Surreal world and environment
+ Complex but enjoyable story
+ Interesting character, item and monster designs
+ Item variety
+ Good sound effects and voice acting
+ The Devs were probably high during this game's production
+ Challenging difficulties

CONS:- Extremely short (4-5 hours game time in my last playthrough)
- Almost no replay value (except for the tower challenge mode)
- Difficult learning curve
- Story is a bit difficult to follow
- Short linear levels (In my opinion, linear games are fine as long as the levels are lengthy and enjoyable)
- No character progression (no armors, level ups or item upgrades)

CONCLUSION:GOOD GAME. Zeno Clash sports a very unique art style that places you in a very surreal world with a strange geography and is populated by strange creatures all brought to life by the developer's clever use of Valve's Source Engine. The combat mechanics is fun albeit a little frustrating at times and hard to learn however, the items does give variety to the player's fighting style. The game should provide you with at least 4-5 hours of game time with its campaign with an added 'Tower Challenge' if the player wants to test his skills.

I RECOMMEND this game mostly for the experience but the short game time could be an issue, still though, Zeno Clash is a fun game to play. I can't honestly cannot recommend it at full price (even if it is only $10 or your regional equivalent), so getting it on a sale is probably a better idea.

Zeno clash is probably one of the more memorable games I've played this year. Set in one of the most creative worlds I have ever witnessed, this game stands out as a real gem to me.

+Well-developed melee fighting where you can lash together combos, strike quickly or strongly, or pick a median attack. Blocking, dodging, countering, finishing. Many great moves to help you deal with the situation at hand.
+Ranged weapons that work fairly well from dual-wielded pistols, rifles, crossbows, or 'grenade launchers'. All very imaginatively designed in a way that they're nothing like you'd imagine based upon how I just described them. Unfortunately they make some fights a little too easy, but without them those same fights would have been a bit too hard.
+It's challenging, but not unfair. Many games today are either too easy, or designed unfairly to promote difficulty. Zeno clash is almost the perfect median between the two.
+The voice acting for the characters is simply splended. Every voice actor was given strange roles to fit, very specific roles, and they all nailed them with excellence.
+Great and memorable characters. From the moral-less Ghat, to the kind and caring Deadra, to the mysterious Father-Mother and all of his-her sons and daughters you face throughout the game. To the also-mysterious Golem, and even to the many unique Corwid you face throughout the game. Oxameter and Gabel being the most memorable.
+The story is confusing to begin with, but as you progress and learn more about what's happening it is fantastic. Absolutely great. Unfortunately it ends in a bit of a cliff hanger but that's fine! We have a sequel available to us!

Zeno Clash is a wierd game that tries to, and succeeds at, doing something that no other FPS has done.  The story is strange, the characters are mysterious, and the player is left continuously wondering what will happen next.  Unfortunately, the story is also not interesting. The game just throws disparate scenario after scenario at you presented as a series of events that happened before the beginning of the game, and it leaves it largely up to you to connect these events.  The characters are not expanded upon, the enemies are only briefly expounded on, and the main characters motivations are left entirely unclear.  I believe this was a choice made deliberately to add mystery to the story, but for me it only left me wanting for a clear reason to continue to my goal.
None of this would be a problem if the game was fun.  I don't need a reason to complete the game if I enjoy playing it.  Zeno Clash is unique in that it tries to blend melee and ranged combat in an FPS in a way I've never seen before.  The melee portion includes blocking, counter attacks, dodging, grabs, and other staples of good melee combat.  The mechanics of the game is what brings it down in this respect.  It would take a long time to describe exactly how frustrating it is to control the combat, but I frequently ended up performing the wrong defensive move which would result in my taking damage.  Furthermore, the counterattacks don't work.  Almost every time I tried to counter an enemy they would block or dodge my counterattack.
The ranged combat has similar problems.  Guns are not meant to be used exclusively.  You are supposed to pick up a weapon and shoot an enemy as many times as you can until they get close to you.  This part feels good.  Watching an enemy running towards you, it feels great to score those two big hits that send them flying on their back then pelting them with more shots until they start towards you again.  When they start getting closer though is when the frustration begins.  When an enemy gets close, you are meant to lock on to put away your weapon and begin melee.  However, running away from an enemy breaks your lock, so if you are trying to get away, the gun comes back out.  If you are hit with the gun out, it drops to the ground with whatever ammo it had, where enemies can pick it up and use it against you.  In short, again, the mechanincs of this game make it very frustrating to do what you want to do, and to fight multiple enemies.
In conclusion, I wanted to like this game.  I like wierd games, I like difficult games, and I like story-driven games.  I HATE frustrating games, however, and this falls squarely into that last category.  The mechanincs of combat don't work, the story was not holding my interest, and I felt no reason to complete the game.  In addition, I found a Zeno Clash process running in the background of my PC even though I hadn't played the game in days and the game itself was not running, so my hours played are inflated.  I should note I did not finish this game.

What the heck is Zeno Clash?

Zeno clash is a first person bang em up type game where the player can punch or kick the crap out of his opponents. Seems like simple fun arcade stuff right? Sort of is, but there are added features to the game (beside the campaign) that make it significant.

The storyline is a good one to say the least. There is a guy who trains you in the game and by the time he's done training you, he simply kills himself. This game is whacky, weird, and odd, but how it all comes together within the world is awesome. When people speak about creative games, this one definitely takes the cake with it's outrageous characters. Besides the game play, the characters alone will make you double take. They are given personalities with extreme oddity that simply makes it appealing. I fought a boss who jumped on top of a bunch of dinosaurs while trying to kill me for pete's sake. I really like the fighting engine and the added features of being able to pick up guns, crossbows, and other sort of crazy weaponry like blunt objects that send opponents flying. When you fight, it actually feels like you're making contact with the opponent. The feedback in the punches was done phenomenally.

Should you buy it? On sale I would say unless you REALLY like these types of games.

For future Zeno Clash games I would recommend multiplayer, and maybe even dare to try to incorporate local co-op. To add to the fighting, perhaps add kicks or even allow for players to hold down the mouse button, then use the mouse to swing to determine the type of swing. Don't make it to the point where people start snapping their mouse cord, but something decently close enough.

reviewText:
A short, but action packed journey in a unique world.

You are on the run, hunted by your own family for the murder of your own father - or better - Father-Mother, aided only by the young woman by your side.
The story is split in two parallel storylines: your present and your past, which will unfold via flashbacks, as you narrate your past and motives to your only remaining friend, and will take you to the very end of the world, before you decide to return home to settle your past once and for all.

Gameplay-wise, the combat in this game is praised as one of the best melee combat experiences in gaming, and while I don't fully agree, I certainly see how it may be so for many people.
You will find an immersive first person combat system, where every punch and every block counts, and mostly, FEELS right.

In the end, it is a short story of ideals and revelations that may even manage to make you think of society as we see it.

Hard to recommend to everyone, although it is so short (I completed it in 5h and I'm sure it can be completed in a little less) that even those who simply seek an alternative adventure won't be too weighed down.

I do recommend it, however, to first person brawlers' fans, you will be given every tool to test your fighting skills.

In short: short, first person brawler with excellent, fleshed out combat and a story with a morale set in a bizarre world.

reviewText:
First person games with good melee combat are sadly rare.  Too often it basically consists of flailing your arms with no force feedback until the enemy falls over (see Elder Scrolls).  Which is a a shame, because when these types of games do show up, they tend to be pretty awesome.
As you can guess, Zeno Clash has good melee combat.  It's fairly simple, but it feels good.  You can dodge and block, punch and throw to your heart's content.  My only real complaint about the combat is that at times it feels a little barebones, especially because the game doesn't force you into most advanced techniques.  I rarely dodged or blocked in my playthrough (although I have yet to do the tower challenges).
The melee segments are broken up by time with various other weapons, and a few boss battles.  I often found myself wishing I could go back to the melee combat (especially during the repetitive fights with heavy enemies), but even these segments were mildly enjoyable at worst and fun at best.
The game also has a pretty good story.  It's simple and short, but it's supported by a wonderfully strange world, and it's fairly engaging.  It ends poorly though, with barely any sense of conclusion.  The game ends up feeling like a prologue for the sequel.

All in all it's a very solid game.  Good melee combat, great world, fun variety of segments.  It's definitely not perfect: It's very short, and it's basically a series of scenes with fades between so it feels at times disjointed and restricting, but it's an enjoyable game, and worth playing if you like unique games or just want to beat up a bunch of weird creatures.

'Zeno Clash' is a debut game by ACE Team, who are the developers who recently released 'Rock of Ages'.

While the gameplay is unvaried and by no means perfect, this reasonably short foray leaves you wanting MORE. For 'Zeno Clash', this is a good thing. This is one game that will have you chomping at the bit for a sequel.

reviewText:
absurdism is difficult. that which is otherworldly, that which is abstract understanding, can only stem from relations of relations of corrupted understandings. people gravitate toward things far removed from understanding. people talk and caw about games having disparate worlds, but zeno clash is true. zeno clash features a world so far removed from anything in fiction or in living. its an absolute triumph of visual direction. zeno clash is a textbook on the deranged. with all of my praise though, it does remind one distinctly of oddworld. however, zeno clash’s world is much more lively - less barren to say - and there are many humans. though there are many other creatures as well.

whatever zeno clash ended up looking like, the base idea is something I would sell myself off for. I am incredibly glad this game exists. beat ‘em ups are eternal for me. what rings incredibly true for zeno clash is how traditional it is. you fight with two kinds of punches, light and heavy. a light punch can strike up to three times and can be comboed into a strong. strong punches are kind of like a wind up punch; space yourself away from your target and dash in with your fist. both are incredibly satisfying thanks to impeccable animation and hit detection. if an enemy becomes dazed, they can be thrown. and that’s basically it. the basic tendency calls back the roots of the beat ‘em up genre, a very comfortable thing for me, and a very different trace of influence for a modern game. especially considering the direction beat ‘em ups have taken with devil may cry, ninja gaiden, and god of war - although those are fantastic titles - it’s nice to see a game toning things back. except, I’d probably enjoy a hyper-complex combat system more, in all honesty.

if zeno clashed revolved around limited arena battles punching the trash out of fugly foes, and in saying that it does anyway, then it’d be a fantastic game that anyone looking for new ideas in their vidcons should play. it wouldn’t raise any intellectual hell, but exist as something more primal than serious sam, with an even goofier atmosphere. the boxing arenas are still totally worth it. but what was a successful formula gets bogged down by forced variance. ace team wasn’t content with the gold they struck - or maybe the gold was struck from altering their original first person shooter formula? either way, there are guns in the game. shoehorned guns. guns that are not fun to shoot or use. if they were options to use in the battle royals then they would be tarnishing, but forgivable. they are not. the gunplay is forced numerous times. thankfully they are not long, yet the damage is still felt. it’s not like anything is broken with the guns - it’s just they’re incredibly mediocre compared to your fists. the endworld is an exception to that with interesting and fun ranged combat. though pacing of using a magic wand leaves some to be desired and the enemies you fight are nothing more than zombies, it’s still darkly enchanting.

ranged weapons present one problem and melee weapons present another. melee weapons have a light swing and a heavy swing, much like your hands. once again, they function like they always have in the genre. they’re usually satisfying to use and offer a break from cracking skulls with your knuckles all day. the problem isn’t in the melee weapons, but when you’re given them. not too often can you use them against normal facepunchers. heavyweight enemies can only be damaged and toppled by heavy weapons and only the charge attack really does any damage. this leads to very mediocre and unsatisfying fights. there are no gambits allowed, no subcombos to pull off, no variety to speak of. you distance yourself, wind up attack, strafe, bash, retreat, repeat. and zeno clash will just throw these fatties at you as the game progresses. they’ll be one with small guys, one coming right after another, and at one point in the game two at a time. the two at a time encounter is pretty damn cool honestly. still, they are static and unfun encounters, and drag down what should be the pinnacle of the game.

if zeno clash had a more organic presentation it would be legendary. if you traversed large and odd levels, fisting waves of enemies, it would have ascended. even if it had rather linear levels with stop and fight sequences, it still would have delivered a wholly amazing game. instead you’re more often that not pitted in smallish arenas to fight your rounds. there are more traditional fps orientated levels to be found, but in those you do not punch, which is all the more confusing. levels are relegated to being plot excerpts filled with gameplay, instead of having the plot compliment the gameplay. its pacing is haphazard and disappointing. it wants to have this grand adventure and yet its levels are arcade in nature. not like double dragon arcade, but dig-dug. they’re just rounds. that feeling is even more horribly accented in the second half when you repeat most of the places you already walked through on your return trip home, just with harder enemies.

sheer repetition is zeno clash’s greatest flaw. guns are no different from eachother besides how many bullets sit in the chamber. melee weapons offer no variation aside from different looking skins. both guns and weapons have wonderful models, but that’s not the kind of variation I’m vying for. there are many different and awesome looking enemies. those many different awesome looking enemies will be fought two to even three times each. their names are the same, I guess they are the same people, but when you fight the same enemies in the same level as a few hours before it feels really freaking lazy. with the two bounty hunter confrontations, both very great despite relying on poor gunplay, it’s more than obvious that ace team really wanted variation in their game. so the design choices in the meat of their game sit in ugly defiance to their vision. a real frustrating execution overall.

writing is stilted. purposefully, the characters need to assume their roles as midsavages. there is a mighty depth and conviction to the script. made up words and made up accents. though, the voice acting does not match the quality of writing, and is rather poor. the story itself, framed as a mystery, compliments the game’s piecemeal length. when it’s all said and done though the plot is a bit flat. it’s not really about what ghat did so much as ghat dealing with why he did it. with the characters being in a generally unrelatable state of mind, the implications aren’t so interesting to learn about. what’s great about the script is the weird things, the corwids, father-mother’s society, the endworld, golem’s crypticness. these things really draw you in. it succeds in vision and skill of writing even if it does not have the running time to tell a deep story.

zeno clash is an addled burst of fraught strangeness smoothed with brand new gameplay. its short length makes it very easy to recommend, but it also is its greatest limiter with unrealized ideas all over the place. zeno clash is a small game and isn’t content with it. because of that, I’m not exactly content with it either.

reviewText:
This is a first person melee brawler, which is quite a new take on the genre. The world is imaginatively designed and the music, while not particularly special is a nice mix of tribal music.

Its a short and linear adventure at around 6 hours. Gameplay is a hit and miss. When the punches connect, they feel satisfying. However, it is frustrating when hit detection goes wonky. There is also a lock-on mechanic, while useful in theory, is a hassle when you need to get away from enemies. While there are also guns, they have too little ammo and load much too slowly to be effective in combat.

The story is simple, but the way its presented is confusing and the characters aren't very memorable. The female sidekick you have doesn't help much at all in combat and would have been much better if she can be used as a co-op partner.

Overall Rating: 6.5 / 10
Not worth to buy full price, but worth a look if on sale. This is an unpolished gem and is a good first effort from this indie studio.

reviewText:
In Zeno Clash, you play as Ghat who is part of a 'family' by this strange creature known as Father-Mother. During the beginning of the game, things won't be very clear except that the supposed brothers and sisters that are a part of this family accuse you of killing Father-Mother. More is revealed as you progress in the game and you eventually find out the truth. Personally, I won't go into further details about the story to avoid spoilers.

The gameplay is very unique in such a way that you don't often see this genre...This game plays in a first person perspective but your use of combat isn't through weapons (there is ranged weapons in the game, but you won't always be using them) instead, you use your fists to beat the ever living crap out of whoever stands in your way. You can lock on to your enemies and switch between which can be handy for quickly knowing when to defend or attack. At some areas of the game, your fists alone won't be reliable enough to hurt some enemies as some of them can vary from big enemies who charge at you and can knock you over resulting in some nasty damage or you have creatures that spit crap at you. So what do you do when it comes down to that? You use weapons! You can pick up some unique looking weapons that help from dual welded bone like pistols to a crossbow that fires skulls that explode upon impact with your enemies or you can have a bone sledgehammer that can deal massive damage to your enemies as you charge your swing.

The level design is incredibly trippy but that's likely what the developers were going for as the world of Zeno Clash is incredibly unreal and is full of plenty of strange yet pretty scenary.

Zeno Clash also has a unique tower mode which you unlock levels of as you progress through the main story. In the tower mode, you are inside a tower killing every enemy in the room to progress higher into the tower and you also also put against a time which shows how long you take. The timer isn't all too important as its just to put you against your friends to see who's faster at the level. As you progress, you'll meet all the different enemies you have met throughout the main game and in some rooms, you will have weapons that you can use or disarm from your enemies. But in the later levels there will also be room hazards that can be useful for killing your enemies in one fell swoop but be careful! As if you aren't, you can also be killed quickly.

All in all, Zeno Clash is a incredibly fun game where you beat the crap out of people and I recommend checking it out if you're looking to punch in some faces! Plus, if you buy it and own Garry's Mod, you'll get all the models from the game!

I think that Zeno Clash is worth playing, especially for the ridiculously low prices for which it can be purchased during sales.

The combat is interesting and varied up until you are required to apply the same mêlée combat techniques to the majority of enemy types. There are more than 10 different fighting moves, without regard for any of the hand-held weapons, but with time you will find certain combinations to be most effective.
During a one-on-one fight you can easily achieve a nice, powerful rhythm - however, when there are many enemies it can be difficult to single one out to focus your efforts.
For less gung-ho players this may result in the tiresome process of wearing multiple enemies down one jab at a time. Drop a grenade amongst foes to speed things up.

From this you may infer that too much of one thing can become dull, so luckily this tedium is broken up by special enemies that require more than fisticuffs.
For example, heavy-set enemies can be overcome by using evasion or timed attacks to bring them to a state of vulnerability. Large, mentally-unstable enemies' weaknesses must be exploited to bring them down to your level so that you may cure their neurosis with, you guessed it, more punching.
This does something to alleviate the familiarity of the dodge-punch-block-kick reptition of fighting, though these types of enemies are, too, used repeatedly.

Sore knuckles and noses is not the only draw card for Zeno Clash, and if you aren't going to play for the combat then please play this game for the fantastic artistic design - for the music, visual art and script.
I found the surreal landscapes and the outlandish flora and fauna to be both beautiful and unsettling. The ramshackle settlements and deformed, (often literally) animalistic citizens had me yearning to see what grotesqueries would arise next and I found this incredibly engaging for the duration of the game. The voices are many and varied, highly emotive and serve to easily differentiate the actors and how they feel towards the protagonist - as well as showing their individual strengths and weaknesses of character.

If you appreciate well-executed gameplay and beautiful art direction then I believe that you will enjoy Zeno Clash as much as I did.
If you have played it already then I urge you to buy it for a friend who has missed out.

reviewText:
One of my first purchases here on Steam. I believe it was back in 2009 if I remember correctly and it did have a very nice discount on it so it was immediately in my basket.

Zeno Clash is an ambitious first person shooter game developed by ACE Team and released in 2009. The game uses the modified version of the Source Engine so it runs very well and while it is somewhat of an aged engine it still - in my opinion - looks good.

Interestingly, rarely do you have the chance to use weapons with projectiles; emphasis is on melee combat and you do have the chance to use some clubs or other heavy weapons beside your fists. Combat is simple but very smooth - the game is very linear and as it is an independent game you can already guess it is quite short.

Story-wise the game is rather silly - it puts you in the shoes of Ghat who is banished from his home after an attempt to kill Father-Mother. Yes, this creature is his father and mother as it seems the entire population of Ghat's settlement was raised by this hermaphroditic creature. Although banished, Ghat wishes to uncover the truth as to what really happened and what secret lies with the family.

Anyways, combat is quite good and the game has a challenge option with levels of a tower to compete against a series of enemies. This is getting difficult gradually - a nice way to pass time once the story mode is finished.

Zeno Clash is somewhat mediocre, but I believe the result of an original idea. If it is on sale this is a highly recommended game.

reviewText:
I have a love-hate relationship with this game. The story was pretty mediocre, but they constantly pull you along with the promise of this huge secret right around every corner. So I was constantly driven to play to figure it out, thinking I was getting closer and closer. Near the end you can figure it out and it’s honestly quite a letdown. The world is interesting and unique, but none of the characters are fleshed out enough for you to really care for them. I have to imagine they had an amazing world in-mind, but were limited in how they could present it. Still there’s plenty of mystery and yearning to find out more.

The gameplay is fluid and has some fun melee components. It's unique in how the game almost plays out like an arena/fighter and FPS game. I had some issues with the controls, like accidently throwing my gun around into unobtainable places, but all in all the combat remained challenging (but not frustratingly so) and never dull.

Regardless of the game's flaws, I can't deny how enthralled I was in the game within the short time it took me to beat it. I would recommend this game to any fans of parachuting squirrels, punching people in the face and mystery.

reviewText: The world of Zenozoik is strange, dirty, and down right alien at times. The character and terrain designs oscillate between beautifully surreal and head-scratchingly mismatched. Everything you see is a wonder to behold and, however improbable, feels as if it belongs there, feels alive. Following Ghat around as he tells his tale and very slowly reveals what he knows was thrilling. No matter how many times he refused to say more, I didn't feel like I was being stalled because it was clear how deeply the secret affected him. His character was fully formed and relatable. But the ending itself felt rushed and not quite as climactic as it seemed to think it was. The big reveal was satisfying, it was the lack of answers pertaining to the newer character that the conclusion centered around that made it somewhat hollow.  If said character was not introduced and the plot remained focused on the conflict between Ghat and Father-mother, I would have no complaints about the storyline. The combat, however, has some issues. Combat is the bulk of game and it never feels quite right. The sights and sounds seem right, when a blow connects there's good feedback, but I never could tell what was and was not going to hit me. The enemies will become invincible at times, during charge up attacks and after being knocked down, which doesn't go along with how the combat itself is presented. There's also not a whole lot to the combat which is a blessing at first, but causes it all to become repetitive later on. In the end, none of that is going to stop me from playing the sequel when the mood hits me, but I'm not exactly rushing into either.

reviewText: Easily one of the most original experiences I've ever seen in a PC game. Making a beat-em-up in a first-person situation was about as clunky as you could imagine, but it came out much better than you'd think. Still, it felt unfair and needlessly frustrating at times. It has a very 80s feel with the design looking like it came out of The Labyrinth and Dark Crystal with the tone of Mad Max and Water World. Zeno Clash is beautifully rendered too with the scenery and chaacter models ooking like they could actually have been made out of clay. The combat, which is the core gameplay, was solid and satisfying despite it's short comings. Never thought I could use the mouse and it feel like I'm really punching somebody! The voice acting is very flat and the story is very shallow, but the story didn't need to be very deep and the awkward voice acting added to the surreal and abstract feel of the whole thing. The music fit the atmosphere and the mood perfectly, similar to Abe's Odysee. I felt like that's probably the sounds you would hear in that universe. Zeno Clash is an easy recommendation for anyone looking for a fresh first person experience with some unique challenge.

reviewText:
Zeno Clash is, and definitely feels like a 10$ game. There's fun to be had here, but not enough to justify a purchase price of over 5$. Absolutely a game that favors style over substance.

Pros:

+ Unique and twisted artstyle
+ Fascinating concept for a game
+ Great soundtrack and beefy sound effects
+ Makes you want the drugs the devs were smoking
+ Pretty funny from time to time
+ Overall PC performance is great

Cons:

- The combat is alright (when it actually works), but it just feels... unresponsive and clunky. Managing more than two enemies at once is practically impossible, because each enemy requires a specific move/dodge for each individual attack, but the game only registers blocks from one enemy. What this means is that you'll be trying to block three incoming attacks, the game will think you're trying to block only one, while the other two land their punches and drain your health. It forces you to A: Run in circles around them and go for fast attacks like a headless chicken, or B: Use a gun (wich also sucks, but I'll get to that later). Fighting several enemies at the same time is just not fun (a melee combat game like Condemned did crowd control right). Mix that with some enemies wich use some really annoying tactics and moves and the fact that the game often thinks you want to kick instead of punch (wich can get you killed, and also some guy though mapping several attacks to one button was a smart idea), the combat just becomes mediocre at best.
- I've played short games, I've played REALLY short games and then I've played zeno clash, wich lasted about 2,5 hours...
- The story is not nearly as deep as advertized. Don't expect much from it
- Practically the most linear game I've ever played, the entire game is a slightly disguised corridor
- The shooting (yes, there are ranged weapons in the game) is underwhelming at best, but sadly what you'll spend most of your time doing, since fighting multiple blokes in hand to hand combat is a pain in the butt
- The bosses (even the final boss) are copy pasted at least twice, and they quickly get boring
- I got such a bad headache from playing this! You know why? Because there's no f#*!ing FOV slider!

I can't really reccomend it unless you REALLY enjoy twisted artstyles, or you want a game to play while hitting the bong.

reviewText:
Regardless of some of the games shortcomings, this game is highly enjoyable with a very pleasurable 1st-person brawler experience makes for some very solid gameplay that is refreshing to enjoy.



I want to get right into things and talk about the combat first. The combat is fun and is surprisingly fluid. Probably one of my biggest issues with the combat system is the enemies invicible times. Enemies can always override your attacks but there's a lot of times when enemies will commit to a attack and are completely invincible. Making it so you take unncessary damage and it kind of ruins the flow of the game I found. Sometimes you can't even dodge their attack when executing a perfect dodge to counterattack. But overrall the combat is fair game.

In the combat you are either using your bare hands to beat the living snot out of your enemies in a awesome intense fashion, or you're picking their health off with a gun from afar.

The combat keeps it very simple with the controls but also makes for some intense fighting. It's really hard to explain how the combat controls work via text over doing a live commentary for example and talking about how they work in the game itself. But the game has a what I'd say fair learning curve with a stiff challenge you may not be prepared for in skill yet. But ultimately you'll learn how to conquer your foes even if it has you going back a chapter or two to do some training. Which really isn't that big of an issue since the fighting in this game is fun as heck. You'll give your old enemies the one-two-puncharoo and you'll pick up some knew combat techniques (skill specifically, the game locks some advanced combat early game. But all results in combat are based on your skill and use of the controls) and be trained enough to learn how to take out tougher enemies.


I liked the soundtrack, it wasn't perfect. But it was nice and I can remember a few specific tracks that fit my fancy. They fit the fighting scenarios well and they really helped you get into fights, I give them credit for making soundtracks that pumped me up some in a lot of these battles and levels.

The art directive was really strange, I wouldn't say it was memorable or enjoyable persay. But it was interesting to look at and look forward to for their next environments and people. Though I had an issue with the level designs. In the sense of the backgrounds. Everything a little above level eye sight which would be the middle of the screen was sickingly blurry. It was like this in pretty much every level. I had to keep my eyes on the ground and the middle of the screen or I felt sick.

The voice acting was poor in it's own right, but that doesn't really matter. Same with the story, the story was kind of weird and didn't really make any sense besides your were just running away from your home because of your actions. But the story and voice acting and art and some of the blurry vision in the levels really pale in how good the action in this game was.


I know I didn't do a good job at explaining the combat at all, i'd definitely suggest watching a video of it on youtube. But the action brawling in this game is really good fun. It was an experience I was happy to partake in and i'm glad I played this game.


I got this game through trading for it, for it was in a bundle. I heard the game was good and I gave it a try and i'm now here to tell you that is indeed the case. I'd suggest getting it price cut of at least above 5 bucks. Anything below that is just criminal. Though this game is priced at $9.99 or your regional equilivalent and I'd say this game is worth the full price. It's good and I can't say i'd feel bad if I dropped ten bucks on this game. Because even after beating the game there's a challenge mode in-which you beat the crap out of people for numerous amounts of floors and that's jolly good fun too.

So anyways, Zeno Clash. If you don't mind a game that is highly action-oriented and with great combat and that's very fast-paced and alive. Get this game, it's really enjoyable.



Anyways, thank you for reading my review. I hope you found it helpful for considering if you want to purchase this game or not, have a good one.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: Grab it during a massively discounted sale"
Traditional Rating: 4/10
Genre: First Person Brawler

I really tried hard to love Zeno Clash - granted the story it tells is certainly innovative and hats off to the developers for bringing something different to the gaming medium - but I just couldn't get into it. I am not going to not recommend you give the game a go even though I have rated it with a non-recommendation because this is probably just due to my personal tastes and since everyone's taste does differ there is a good possibility you could walk away really loving this title.

Set in a far away fantasy world the game makes use of the Source Engine from Valve to tell its tale and it looks pretty decent and runs easily on modern machines. The fantasy world created is quite eye-catching but that was not nearly enough to keep me invested in the game which I found to be dreadfully boring and far too hipster for its own good. Even the convoluted story involving your character and his accidental killing of a creature known as Father-Mother and his then flight from the town he once called home all the while being pursued by his brother and sisters who are hot on his heels with the intention to kill him didn't really resonate with me either. I didn't really enjoy the fighting mechanics and got more frustrated with the game as time moved on.

Don't go by what I say as anything gospel since there are many out there who absolutely adore this little title and you may end up being one of them. It's just not for me!"

Zeno Clash is good because it's interesting, and not because it's particularly well made. The combat is interesting, although I found it hard to dodge because it's a two-action sequence (block and then move) instead of a chord or single button. Zeno Clash was developed by ACE Team, an entertainment software developer based in Santiago, Chile.  They're committed to making unique games that stand out for their originality and quality.

Zeno Clash is exactly that; the use of the Source engine makes for excellent graphics and  a quality feel, while it's unique art style, story line, and melee combat system really sets this game apart from your typical half-♥♥♥♥♥ console port.

JohnCover gives you his recommendation.

This is a First Person Brawler with a simple combat system, original and out of the ordinary art style. Featuring a 2-3 hour story mode and another hour of challenges.

Graphics: The game uses the Source engine (Half Life 2) so it has limited but memorable scenes. The art style is astonishing and  aestheticly looks like a wierd dream.
I really want to see the concept arts or a sketchbook from the creator. Technically the game looks okay. There are low res textures, jerky shadows and low poly stuff. But the caracter design, the weapons and the environment...man this game looks and feels really uniqe.

Sound: The music just like the graphics fullfills this wierd dreamy athmosphere. There are many memorable moments thank to the great combination of them. Voice acting is cheesy but funny. The dialogues are genuinely funny and serious at the same time. The sound effects are basic public domain stuff.

Gameplay: Gameplay wise well... it's simple. The main scenario is arena fight. You get to a locked area and you have to defeat all the enemies. Imagine these like nodes in a graph. These nodes are connected by edges that are basically linear paths. And overall the game is linear and the level design is linear too.
There is a turret section as well but still has the stong dreamy athmosphere so it's okay. You will encounter little enemies, normal enemies, normal enemies with weapons (melee, ranged), brutes and bosses.
The little enemies are crabs, chickens and those big rabbit thingys. I think most of them just spit you acid liquid. Normal enemies are basically fighting partners. These guys can pick up weapons as well. Enemy vaiety is nice here because there are different models and fighting styles. Brutes are big, tough enemies and you better kill 'em with melee weapons. They take multiple hits as well. Bosses are easy battles, just like old times: wasd 'em and shoot 'em.
You can shoot only in ADS otherwise you swing the weapon towards the enemy. You can throw the weapons as well. Mechanically these are the same as in other games but they feel strange and uniqe in a positive way.
The melee system is simple and easy to learn. There are basic combos and advanced combos. The game does a good job teaching you these things in the tutorial sessions. There is a challenge tower for pro players. It's basically a fight fest. You have to climb the tower and defeat all the enemies. Things could get hard here... :)

Replayability: As I mentioned the Singleplayer story mode is linear and each replay will be the same. But if you liked the story and the wierd things in it, I'm sure you'll give it another go. However the Challenge Tower is pure gameplay and fun and absolutely replayable.

Overall:  Pros:
Short but entertaining Singleplayer mode
Visceral combat
Simple and fun melle system
Uniqe aesthetics
Interesting art style
Dreamy music
Cons:
Short Singleplayer mode
Lack of MP features
Mediocre sound effects

This by far is one of the most visually interesting games I've ever played. The aesthetics are totally atypical from what you would expect to find in really any other game, but they're not garish or overbearing. You'll find yourself in a highy atmospheric, if not visceral fantasy world beating up everything that moves. The combat is fairly unique too, being a first person beat-em-up, and at times it can feel delayed and clunky, and with some of the weapons you're given, almost useless, but it is overall an interesting first step in a world and genre that has previously not existed. Although fairly linear, the world is still expansive, and although many enemies are recycled, you still feel a large variation in what you're fighting. The voice acting is reminiscent of Deus Ex, but overall the game is worthy of a purchase and a play for all gamers casual to hardcore.

When discussing what games can do as a medium of expression, I tend to lean towards either the mechanics as meaning or just an excellent sense of place arguments. Zeno Clash is definitely the latter, creating a world that though has existed in visual expressions before but hasn't been covered in video games.\n\nWhether fighting pig people in a Dr. Suess-esque capital city, or shooting sand people with your fish gun on a boat trip, Zeno Clash provides you with more visually stunning environmnets that I've only seen rivaled in Morrowind and Bioshock.

Authors must have been on drugs or in a mental asylum in order to create this game. But who cares, it worked! This game is surreal, weird and awesome. It's basically a first-person brawler simulator in a post-apocalyptic or alternate reality mutated savage world. And I have enjoyed it greatly.\n\nThe graphics, even though based on an old Source engine, is outstanding to this day. The story is very engaging. And the brawler system itself is probably the best one I've ever seen. There is a large number of different moves and their modifiers, but they are very natural and intuitive. The fighting moves are fluent, and the fistfights have great dynamics of alternating attacks with counterattacks/dodging. Fighting several enemies at once is very challenging, as it should. The overall fighting experience is absolutely great.

It's difficult to explain why I enjoyed this game as much as I did.  I enjoyed it for the story, and yet it has a heavy combat focus, and feels like a series of set pieces.  Surprisingly though, the set pieces weave together like the chapters of a good book, and the whole thing just works, with a wonderfully bizarre art style.  It's like someone put together a dish of all my favourite foods, without thought as to how they work together, and yet everything is so good that it works anyway.
